text:
Over the last few billion years, species have
appeared and disappeared from our planet like
guests at an open-house party.

Sometimes they’ve shown up in droves, making
the party swell with new forms of life, and

other times, the majority of the guests have
headed for the exit virtually all at once.

The first big swell came about 550 million
years ago, when the earliest animals appeared

and diversified into virtually all the basic
body shapes we know today.

One hundred million years later, the warm,
shallow seas were packed with tiny plants

and animals – essentially, hors d'oeuvres
for a plethora of bigger creatures like trilobites,
conodonts, brachiopods, and corals.

But just a million years after that, four
out of five of the world’s marine species
were gone.

Only the rock record can tell us what happened
to them, but most ancient rocks have been
scattered, buried, or destroyed over time.

The best clues we’ve uncovered so far come
from Northern Africa, which, 450 million years

ago, was part of a supercontinent near the
South Pole.

Outcrops dating back to that time contain
the track-marks of an ice sheet’s vast expansion,

as well as piles of rocky debris left by its
rapid melt.

What’s more, the mass extinction appears
to have unfolded in two distinct pulses, one

in sync with the ice sheet’s growth, the
other with its retreat.

In other words, it seems that our planet’s
first major party killer was an ice age.

And yet, this revelation has created more
questions than it has answered.

Much of the life in the shallows probably
perished as the growing ice sheet locked up

more and more of the world’s water, but
why did so many deep-water organisms disappear
along with them?

And why did some species survive the ice age,
only to die as seas rose and temperatures
warmed at its finish?

And why did this particular ice age wreak
more havoc on life than any cold snap since?

The answers to these questions are probably
all out there somewhere, just waiting for
us to unearth them.
